Table 4 Model Favorable mechanism Barrier/eV Reference Pt-graphene ER 0.33 [16] Pd-graphene TER 0.08 [63] Mo-graphene ER 0.60 [64] Fe-graphene LH 0.58 [65] Fe-BN LH 0.52 [24] Pd-BN LH 0.64 [66] Co-BN ER 0.41 [67] Ni-BN ER 0.68 [68] CO oxidation on atomic nickel/phosphorene nanosheet: An efficient single-atom catalyst Donglin Li Wenliang Li ⁎ Jingping Zhang ⁎ Faculty of Chemistry, Northeast Normal University, Changchun 130024, China Faculty of Chemistry Northeast Normal University Changchun 130024 China Faculty of Chemistry, Northeast Normal University, Changchun 130024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Various metals decorated phosphorene nanosheet as single-atom catalyst (SAC) for CO oxidation have been investigated systematically by employing spin-polarized density functional theory. Ni-phosphorene is found to be the promising SAC for CO oxidation after comparing with other noble and non-noble metal candidates, such as Fe, Co, Cu, Al, Ag, Au, and Pt. Moreover, the structure of Ni-phosphorene remains stable at the end of 5 ps under 300 K using first-principles molecular dynamics simulations. Additionally, O2 and CO are difficult to dissociate on Ni-phosphorene at room temperature because their dissociation energies are greater than 1 eV in possible paths. Three feasible reaction mechanisms (Langmuir-Hinshelwool (LH), Eley-Rideal, and Termolecular Eley-Rideal) are taken into account to seek the path with the lowest energy barrier. The LH mechanism is the most favorable one with the lowest energy barrier (0.59 eV) in the rate-determining step, which is facile to occur under ambient temperature. Our results provide theoretical guidance to design highly active heterogeneous catalysts based on phosphorene substrate for CO oxidation at low temperature. Graphical abstract A single atom catalyst Ni-phosphorene can catalyze CO oxidation with low activation energy of 0.59 eV for rate-determining step. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phosphorene Density functional theory CO oxidation Single-atom catalyst LH mechanism 1 Introduction Air pollution is an important environmental problem, and the continuous consumption of fossil fuels and unending activities of human beings have resulted in a mass emission of harmful gasses like CO, SO2, and nitrogen oxides [1]. Among these, the conversion of CO has attracted an enormous amount of research [2]. The most widely investigated method is to convert CO into the harmless gas CO2 through an oxidation process [3,4]. In addition, the CO oxidation is meaningful on account of its significance in practical applications, such as handling the released CO from producing activities or removing CO out of hydrogen storage containers [1–4]. Noble metals Rh [5], Pd [6], and Pt [7] based materials can catalyze CO conversion directly. Nevertheless, the noble metal-based catalysts need high operation temperature and cost, meantime with low efficiency due to the cluster formation tendency [3–7]. These disadvantages can't satisfy noble metal catalysts widespread applications. Therefore, the design and synthesis of high-efficiency catalysts for CO oxidation is imperative [8]. The concept of single-atom catalyst (SAC) was proposed by Qiao et al., which verified the single Pt atom doped the FeOx surface can promote CO oxidation with good catalytic activity, and no obvious cluster formed on this new-type catalyst [9]. Ever since, great attention has been aroused experimentally and theoretically to find appropriate catalytic atoms and substrate materials to synthesize SAC for fundamentally chemical reactions like CO oxidation, N2 reduction reaction, and methane-methanol conversion processes, and so on [10–15]. Many researches mainly focused on the two-dimensional (2D) materials, in which graphene and its derivatives were investigated extensively due to their unique catalytic property [10–12]. Experimentally, Co, Fe, and Pd doped into graphene were found to catalyze CO oxidation, benzene oxidation, and hydrogenation reaction, respectively [13–15]. Theoretically, Pt and Pd doped into graphene [16,17], Fe and Mn doped into penta-graphene and oxide graphene were predicted and confirmed to catalyze CO oxidation [18–20]. Besides graphene based SACs, other 2D materials based SACs such as Cr supported on phthalocyanine (Pc) monolayer were predicted to catalyze CO oxidation effectively [21]. Later experimental and theoretical investigations proved that MoS2 [22], C2N [23], and boron nitride [24] possess well catalytic performance for CO oxidation reaction. Also, the bulk phase materials like CeO2 [25], TiO2 [26], and Al2O3 [27] were verified to serve as substrate material of SACs for CO oxidation. Apparently, the catalytic metal, the substrate material, and their binding style have great influence in the catalytic effect [21–23]. Hence, selecting applicable atomic metal and substrate material are crucial for designing high-efficiency SACs [24–26]. Recently, phosphorene as a new-type 2D material was synthesized successfully by exfoliation techniques from the layered black phosphorene [28]. Subsequently, many studies of phosphorene were conducted. The results indicated that phosphorene possesses great physical, chemical, catalytic and electrical characteristics [29,30]. The electron transport methods manifested that phosphorene performs high mobility when worked as field-effect transistor [31–35]. The phosphorene doped by light metals Al and Li were predicted to possess strong adsorption capacity of acidic gasses such as CO2, SO2, and NO2, which allows efficient reduction of the content of acidic gasses in the environment [36,37]. Moreover, transition metals such as Fe, Ni, and Cu supported phosphorene can enhance the adsorption capacity of O2 [38]. Fe and Mn doped into phosphorene can catalyze N2 fixation and hydrogen evolution reactions with a low overpotential [39–44], and noble metal Ru supported phosphorene has catalytic potential for CO oxidation shown through density functional theory (DFT) calculations [45], respectively. These results indicate that phosphorene has unexpected gas adsorption and catalytic abilities as well [34–45]. Inspired by those SAC reports mentioned above, a systematic study has been employed on the basis of ab-initio computations to seek suitable metal atom to design effective SAC to catalyze CO oxidation, by comparing the adsorption behavior of related adsorbates in the conditions of metal supported and doped phosphorene surface. Al, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Au, Ag, and Pt were taken into account because they have been demonstrated to be promising catalytic atoms in SAC. We expect the phosphorene-based catalyst can provide an original perspective in SAC filed for CO conversion reaction. 2 Computational details All computations were executed using spin-polarized DFT as implemented in the Dmol3 module [46]. The core-valence effect was manifested by the DFT semi-core pseudopotentials (DSPP) [47]. The exchange-correlation energy function was described by the Grimme's scheme (Al, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) and TS scheme (Au, Ag, and Pt) for dispersion correction [48,49]. The exchange-correlation function was expressed by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) within the Perdew-Burke-Ernzernhof (PBE) functional [50]. The double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set was adopted during the whole process [51]. To balance the computational cost and precision, a 4 × 4 × 1 phosphorene (P) supercell was constructed as the catalytic substrate to simulate CO oxidation process [52,53]. The internal freedoms were completely relaxed but the volume and shape of the phosphorene supercell was fixed in the processes of seeking the optimal structures and transition state steps. The distance between adjacent slabs was set to 20 Å for the sake of avoiding mutual effect between neighboring monolayers. The convergence tolerances for the force, the replacement, and the energy were set to 2.0 × 10−3 Ha/Å, 5.0 × 10−3 Å, and 10−5 Ha, respectively. The Brillouin-zone integration k-point was sampled with 3 × 3 × 1 to guarantee the computational accuracy. The transition states (TS) is identified by the complete linear synchronous transit (LST)/quadratic synchronous transit (QST) method. The climbing image nudged elastic band method (NEB) was adopted to seek the minimum-energy paths (MEP) [54]. The ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were set in NVT ensemble at 300 K for 5 ps to verify the structural stability. The charge results are based on Mulliken analysis method. The binding energy (E b) is used to indicate the bond strength of phosphorene and the atomic metal. It is presented as E b = E M − p h o s p h o r e n e − E p h o s p h o r e n e − E M where the E M-phosphorene, E phosphorene, and E M are the energies of the phosphorene-metal complex, the phosphore supercell, and the isolated atomic metal in gas-phase (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Al, Ag, Au, and Pt), respectively. The adsorption energy (E ad) is employed to describe the adsorption capacity of O2, CO, and CO2 molecules. It is defined as E ad = E M − p h o s p h o r e n e − g a s − E M − p h o s p h o r e n e − E g a s where the E M-phosphorene-gas, E M-phosphorene, and E gas are the total energies of O2, CO, and CO2 adsorbed M-phosphorene, the M-phosphorene, and the individual gas in gas-phase, respectively. The rate constants (k) of considered reaction mechanisms under different temperatures were calculated according to the harmonic transition-state theory (HTST) [55,56]. It is formulated as k = k B T h exp ( − Δ G a R T ) where k B is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature, h is the Plank constant, R is the universal gas constant, and ΔG a is the Gibbs free energy of activation. The ΔG a is the Gibbs free energy difference between the transition state and the reactant state, which can be obtained via G = H – TS. The enthalpy (H) and entropy (S) are expressed as H T = E elc + Z P E + E v i b ( T ) + E r o t ( T ) + E t r a n s ( T ) + R T S T = S vib ( T ) + S r o t ( T ) + S t r a n s ( T ) where the E elc and ZPE are the electronic energy and zero-point energy, and the E vib (S vib), E rot (S rot), and E trans (S trans) mean the thermal contributions of vibrational, rotational, and translational degrees of freedom at different T. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Seeking suitable metal atom on phosphorene monolayer A 4 × 4 × 1 pristine phosphorene supercell was built to satisfy the requirements of the simulated CO oxidation. The optimized structure and energy gap of phosphorene are given in Fig. S1, and its geometrical parameters and the energy gap with the value of 0.90 eV are close to the other computational works [36–39]. Then eight common metals were adopted to seek the proper metal for stably support/doping on phosphorene monolayer. The supported behavior of various metals on the phosphorene surface was investigated firstly. The supported configurations and the relevant gas adsorption behaviors are displayed in Figs. S2, S3. The computed E b, the distance between metals and phosphorene (d), the charge of metals (Q M), and the E ad of the gas molecule within various metals supported phosphorene are shown in Table 1 . A more negative value of E b means stronger bond strength of phosphorene and the atomic metal. A more negative value of E ad means better gas adsorption capacity. The E b of these metals are quite close to previous study (such as −3.31 eV vs −3.25 eV of Fe, −4.28 eV vs −4.16 eV of Co, −4.65 eV vs −4.55 eV of Ni) [38], and the E ad of associated adsorbates in the case of Au and Pt are similar with other reports (such as Au-phosphorene: −0.83 eV vs −0.81 eV of O2, −1.16 eV vs −1.12 eV of CO, −0.12 eV vs −0.14 eV of CO2; Pt-phosphorene: −1.19 eV vs −1.11 eV of O2, −1.98 eV vs −1.93 eV of CO, −0.15 eV vs −0.18 eV of CO2) [37,45]. On the whole, all metals possess good combination ability with phosphorene due to their more favorable | E b |, and shorter d corresponds to stronger | E b | except Al and Pt. Furthermore, the E ad of related adsorbates on phosphorene are significant. It is interesting to note that this series of metal phosphorene complexes can adsorb O2 and CO effectively, and it is accompanied with small | E ad | of CO2. By comparison, Fe has relatively appropriate E ad of O2 (−1.93 eV), CO (−1.80 eV), and CO2 (−0.23 eV), as well Fe is a non-noble metal. Therefore, Fe has potential to be supported on the phosphorene surface and catalyze CO oxidation. The diffusion issue was taken into account to verify the stability of the compound under room temperature with supported Fe. Two paths were designed from the hexagonal supported site to its horizontally and vertically neighbouring supported sites, as shown in Fig. S4a. It is reported that the diffusion behavior may occur in case the diffusion energy barrier being lower than 1.0 eV [57]. The diffusion energies of paths I and II are 0.64 eV and 0.81 eV. As a result, Fe is likely to diffuse along path I and form the clusters. Hence, Fe supported phosphorene tends to form cluster with adjacent Fe atoms, instead of being stably supported on the phosphorene alone on account of the diffusion issue. On the basis of the above results, the status of supported metal is not reasonable for the CO oxidation. To avoid the cluster formation due to the metal diffusion on phosphorene, the atomic metal should be doped on phosphorene surface by substituting one P atom rather than supported on phosphorene. Previous studies proved the feasibility of this doping method [58,59]. Figs. S5 and S6 describe the structures of metals doped phosphorene and the corresponding gas adsorption behaviors. The E b, the charge of metals, and the adsorption energy of the gas molecule within various metals doped phosphorene are shown in Table 2 . These metals have better bond strength with the defective phosphorene because their |E b| are more favorable than the corresponding supported circumstances. Similarly, the E ad of O2, CO, and CO2 were also calculated to evaluate the CO oxidation status. Among eight candidates, Al, Fe, Co, and Ni have more favorable |E ad| of O2 and CO, and all doped compounds own weak physical adsorption for CO2. For the sake of selecting the most advantageous doping metal, the energy gap was calculated to estimate the conductivity of Al, Fe, Co, and Ni doped complexes, as shown in Fig. S7. It can be seen that the energy gap of theses four metals doped phosphorene can be reduced at varying levels, compared with the pristine phosphorene. Especially in Ni-phosphorene, the energy gap is decreased to zero, indicating Ni could enhance the conductivity remarkably and lead to the transformation from semiconductor to conductor of phosphorene. Thus, Ni is regarded as the best candidate to be doped on phosphorene. Additionally, the partial density of states (PDOS), the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMO) of Ni doped complex were obtained to investigate the interaction effect between the atomic Ni and phosphorene (Figs. S8, S9). The PDOS displays obvious hybridization between Ni-3d and P-3p orbitals by the emerging overlaps near the Fermi level, which indicates Ni atom combines well with phosphorene (Fig. S8). The HOMO-LUMO analysis also shows that the interaction of Ni and phosphorene monolayer is mainly contributed by the Ni-3d and P-3p orbitals, manifesting that Ni can be active doping metal for phosphorene (Fig. S9). The ab-initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations was adopted to check the stability of Ni-phosphorene (Fig. S10). The structure of Ni-phosphorene remains integrated without obvious deformation, distinct energy or the temperature alteration via AIMD simulations. The bond distances between Ni and its nearest P atoms are 2.21 Å, 2.23 Å, and 2.28 Å, which are close to the initial distances with the value of 2.18 Å and 2.19 Å, respectively. It demonstrates the complex can remain stable at ambient temperature. Likewise, clusters issue induced by the atomic metal diffusion should be considered as well. Three possible diffusion paths of Ni from the doped site to its neighboring hollow sites (path I, path II, and path III) were designed to simulate this circumstance as depicted in Fig. S4b, and the diffusion energies of three paths are 4.12, 3.20, and 1.99 eV, respectively. It is noticeable that they are much higher than the critical diffusion energy of 1.0 eV [57]. The results manifest that the atomic Ni is difficult to diffuse at ambient temperature and can be doped stably on phosphorene. Therefore, Ni has the catalytic potential as the SAC for CO oxidation, and hereafter our discussion mainly focuses on the Ni based SAC. 3.2 Gasses adsorption behaviors on Ni-phosphorene In order to reflect the preferable gas adsorption on this Ni based SAC surface in detail, the calculated E ad, the distance between gasses and Ni-phosphorene (d), and the charge in gasses and Ni-phosphorene (Q Ni, Q gas) are given in Table 3 , and the most favorable adsorption configurations on pristine phosphorene and Ni doped phosphorene are depicted in Fig. 1 . It can be found that, Ni-phosphorene has larger E ad and shorter d between the relative adsorbates and the compound comparing with the bare phosphorene. For O2 adsorption (Figs. 1a, 1e), the most favorable configuration is the side-on style, in which the O2 molecule is adsorbed to the substrate in parallel. The E ad of this O2 is −1.36 eV on Ni-phosphorene (vs −0.16 eV on bare phosphorene). The distance between the two O in O2 and Ni atom is 1.89 Å (vs 3.43 Å on pure phosphorene), and the OO bond is prolonged from to 1.37 Å (vs 1.23 Å in individual O2). The Mulliken charge analysis demonstrates the main charge transfer from Ni (reducing 0.20 e) to O2 (increasing 0.13 e). These results indicate that the OO bond is activated effectively on Ni-phosphorene. As for CO adsorption behavior (Figs. 1b, 1f), which is important in the process of CO oxidation, two adsorption patterns of C atom or O atom (Cend, Oend) towards Ni were simulated, in which the Cend is more favorable, and the E ad of this CO is −1.23 eV on Ni-phosphorene (vs −0.38 eV on bare phosphorene). The Ni-Cend distance is 1.82 Å (vs 2.38 Å on pristine phosphorene), and the CO bond is enlarged to 1.16 Å (vs 1.13 Å in isolated CO). Meanwhile, the charge transfer between Ni and CO is observed (Ni loses 0.10 e, CO gains 0.04 e). Above results demonstrate that the Ni-phosphorene can activate CO validly. With regard to CO2 adsorption, it was found to be the weakest with the E ad of −0.22 eV (−0.12 eV on bare phosphorene), which suggests that CO2 can be readily removed spontaneously under ambient temperature (Figs. 1c, 1g). Additionally, the atomic O can adsorb on Ni-phosphorene firmly, and the E ad of this O is −5.19 eV (vs −2.85 eV for bare phosphorene), in the meantime the atomic O gains 0.38 e (Figs. 1d, 1h). The results thus signify that the O −can be formed, which facilitates the reaction process. To further explore the reason of mutual effects between the reactive adsorbates (O2, CO) and the Ni-phosphorene, the PDOS, the orbital analysis, and the charge density difference (CDD) of O2 Ni-phosphorene and CONi-phosphorene were exhibited in Figs. 2 , 3 , 4 , respectively. In PDOS analysis, the Ni-3d, O2–2p, and CO-2p are paramount contribution in orbital composition of Ni, O2, and CO, respectively. Meanwhile, the hybridization near the Fermi level results from the Ni-3d and O2–2p orbitals, as well the CO-2p orbitals proves that the existence of mutual effect between the adsorbates and Ni-phosphorene (Fig. 2). For the orbital consequences of O2 and CO adsorption systems, the HOMO and LUMO located between adsorbate and Ni-phosphorene surface, indicating the adsorbed region has apparent interaction (Fig. 3). From the perspective of CDD (Fig. 4), the electron transfer exists in the interface of adsorbate and Ni-phosphorene monolayer. The electrons are lost from Ni-phosphorene surface and gained by the adsorbate, which is identical with the Mulliken analysis. These results illustrate that Ni can be the effectively active site for O2 and CO adsorption. Furthermore, to check the thermodynamic stability of O2, CO adsorbed systems, the AIMD simulations were performed as shown in Fig. 5 . The structures of two adsorbed systems are still integrated without any remarkable deformation, energy or temperature variation. The OO bond and two Ni-O bonds of O2 Ni-phosphorene are 1.35 Å, 1.84 Å, and 2.01 Å (Fig. 5a), and the CO and Ni-O bonds of CONi-phosphorene are 1.18 Å and 1.81 Å (Fig. 5c) via AIMD simulations. They are fairly close to the initial adsorption structures as shown in Fig. 1. The AIMD results demonstrate the thermal stability of O2 Ni-phosphorene and CONi-phosphorene complexes at room temperature. In addition, another issue should be explored is that the possibility of gas dissociation. The possible dissociation paths for O atom both in adsorbed O2 and CO molecules include the neighboring P sites (N1, N2), the adjacent hollows (H1, H2, H3), and the nearest bridge site (B1), as stated in Fig. S11. The results turn out that the dissociated O atom can not locate at H1, H2, H3, or B1 sites stably, and it will move to N1 site from H1 and B1 sites, and to N2 site from H2 and H3 sites after structural optimizations. Therefore, the likely dissociation positions are N1 and N2 sites for the O atom in O2 and CO. The dissociation energies for the O atom of O2 and CO are 2.98 eV and 5.26 eV to N1 site, and 1.16 eV and 2.88 eV to N2 site, which are higher than the critical value of 1.0 eV and difficult to occur under room temperature. This further suggests that the Ni-phosphorene has potential to conduct CO oxidation. In general, two fundamental reaction paths have been studied broadly already (Langmuir-Hinshelwool (LH) and Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanisms). In the LH mechanism, O2 and CO would co-adsorb on the SAC platform simultaneously prior to the reaction. In the ER mechanism, O2 adsorbs on the SAC monolayer ahead of the reaction, and CO approaches to the adsorbed O2 to initiate the catalytic reaction [18,60–62]. Lately, a new reaction path namely the Termolecular Eley-Rideal (TER) has been discovered. For TER, two isolated CO molecules preadsorb synchronously, and the O2 in gas phase moves towards the surface to form two CO2 simultaneously [17]. These three reaction paths are explored systematically in the later sections. 3.3 LH mechanism The first CO oxidation via LH mechanism depicts in Fig. 6 a. IS, TS, MS, and FS represent the initial state, transition state, intermediate state, and final state, respectively. It begins from the co-adsorption condition, and the E ad of O2 and CO is −2.01 eV (IS1). For IS1, the distance of OO in O2 is extended to 1.36 Å (vs 1.23 Å in the individual O2) and the distance of CO in CO is slightly activated to 1.14 Å (vs 1.13 Å in the isolated CO). O2 and CO chemical bonds are activated in IS1 status. Whereafter, the adsorbed O2 rotates to the C atom in CO by means of TS1 to form the carbonate like OCOO (MS1). This step is exothermic by 0.21 eV, and the activation energy is 0.59 eV, indicating the occurrence under ambient temperature. Next, the OO bond of OCOO is dissociated via TS2 to generate the first CO2 (FS1). The activation energy of this process is only 0.04 eV, with releasing the amount of heat of 2.08 eV. The formed CO2 is far away from the Ni-phosphorene sheet with the distance of 2.99 Å and the E ad of the CO2 is −0.15 eV, suggesting the easy release of CO2 from the monolayer of Ni-phosphorene, corresponding to the finish of first CO oxidation reaction. Meanwhile, the isolated atomic O of O2 exits firmly on Ni-phosphorene with the E ad of −5.19 eV, which can promote following CO oxidation process. Subsequently, the second CO oxidation is shown in Fig. 6b, starting from the adsorbed O and the other CO in gas phase (IS2), and the CO moves towards the remaining O to generate the second CO2 (MS2) through TS3. This process needs the activation energy of 0.27 eV and releases the heat by 2.32 eV. The E ad of this CO2 on Ni-phosphorene is −0.22 eV, favoring its release from the monolayer to recover the initial status for the rest CO oxidation reaction. The rate-determination step (RDS) is TS1, with the activation energy of 0.59 eV and the released energy of 4.57 eV in LH mechanism for the whole reaction. 3.4 ER mechanism The catalytic CO oxidation occurs by ER is demonstrated in Fig. 7 a. Starting from the pre-adsorbed O2 and the CO in gas phase (IS3) due to the favorable E ad than that of CO. Later, the CO approaches to O2 to form OCOO carbonate like intermediate (MS2) via TS4, and it requires to overcome the energy barrier of 1.02 eV, and it is endothermic with the value of 0.31 eV. Next, the MS2 generates one CO2 and one of the O atom of O2 is adsorbed on Ni stably (FS3) via TS5. This step shows the activation energy by 0.46 eV, and releases the heat of 2.16 eV. This formed CO2 has the E ad of −0.16 eV with the distance of 3.03 Å to the Ni-phosphorene surface, which is facile to be released on the Ni-phosphorene surface. Then, the isolated remaining O of O2 is adsorbed stably with the E ad of −5.19 eV. The following process is like the second CO oxidation process as illustrated in Fig. 6b, and this step will overcome the activation energy of 0.27 eV and the liberated heat is 2.32 eV. The RDS is TS4, with the activation energy of 1.02 eV and the released heat of 4.17 eV in ER mechanism. 3.5 TER mechanism TER mechanism is elaborated as Fig. 7b, which starts from the two CO co-adsorbed on Ni-phosphorene and the individual O2 (IS4). The two CO bonds are prolonged from 1.13 Å to 1.16 Å, which is 0.02 Å longer than the CO of co-adsorbed CO and O2 in LH (vs 1.14 Å). The E ad of the two CO molecules is −2.09 eV, which means that both of co-adsorbed CO are activated effectively. Next, the free O2 moves to the two CO to form two CO2 directly (FS4) via TS5, and this step needs to overcome the activation energy of 3.21 eV and releases the energy of heat by 3.69 eV. This high energy barrier (3.21 eV) is ascribed to the O2 being not activated adequately. By comparing the three reaction paths in the views of activation energy and reaction energy, the RDS energy barriers of the LH, ER, and TER are 0.59 eV, 1.02 eV, and 3.21 eV with the released energies of 4.57 eV, 4.17 eV, and 3.69 eV, respectively. Among them LH mechanism has the lowest energy barrier and the highest enthalpy release, indicating LH being the most preferable for CO oxidation. The Ni-phosphorene is comparable to another phosphorene based SAC in which noble metal Ru supported phosphorene has the energy barrier of 0.44 eV for the RDS [45]. More importantly, Ni-phosphorene has unexpected catalytic ability for CO oxidation even compared with other 2D materials like graphene and boron nitride based SACs as shown in Table 4 . 3.6 Rate constants On the basis of HTST [55,56], the reaction rate constants of the three mechanisms are plotted in Fig. 8 . It is found that LH mechanism possesses higher rate constant at all temperatures compared with ER and TER. Especially, under low temperature such as 298 K, only LH has positive k, which corresponds with the lower energy barrier of LH mechanism in the first CO oxidation process. The rate constants of three mechanisms are in direct proportion as the temperature increases. And at around 435 K and 862 K, the k of ER and TER mechanisms would increase to positive values. In short, LH mechanism makes the main contribution and it would occur at room temperature for CO oxidation. 4 Conclusion In general, we screened eight noble and non-noble metals Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Al, Ag, Au, and Pt doped phosphorene substrate to design SAC for CO oxidation. Ni-phosphorene shows great preferable adsorption capacity for O2, CO and catalytic ability for CO oxidation reaction. Meanwhile, it can avoid the dissociation of O2 and CO with the high dissociation energies, and the structures of Ni-phosphorene, O2 Ni-phosphorne, CONi-phosphorene keep stably at 300 K after 5 ps of AIMD simulations. Three possible reaction mechanisms (LH, ER, and TER) were calculated systematically. The LH mechanism exhibited the higher catalytic ability with reaction energy barrier of 0.59 eV for the RDS than the ER and TER mechanisms (1.02 eV and 3.21 eV for energy barrier in RDS, respectively). Ni-phosphorene is a potential candidate as SAC for CO oxidation, as far as the energy barrier of the RDS (0.59 eV) is concerned. Moreover, it is comparable to the graphene, boron nitride, and other typically 2D materials based SAC. Our results are expected to assist experimentalists to design promising non-noble heterogeneous SAC based on phosphorene. coredata.dc:description: Various metals decorated phosphorene nanosheet as single-atom catalyst (SAC) for CO oxidation have been investigated systematically by employing spin-polarized density functional theory. Ni-phosphorene is found to be the promising SAC for CO oxidation after comparing with other noble and non-noble metal candidates, such as Fe, Co, Cu, Al, Ag, Au, and Pt. Moreover, the structure of Ni-phosphorene remains stable at the end of 5 ps under 300 K using first-principles molecular dynamics simulations. Additionally, O2 and CO are difficult to dissociate on Ni-phosphorene at room temperature because their dissociation energies are greater than 1 eV in possible paths. Three feasible reaction mechanisms (Langmuir-Hinshelwool (LH), Eley-Rideal, and Termolecular Eley-Rideal) are taken into account to seek the path with the lowest energy barrier. The LH mechanism is the most favorable one with the lowest energy barrier (0.59 eV) in the rate-determining step, which is facile to occur under ambient temperature. Our results provide theoretical guidance to design highly active heterogeneous catalysts based on phosphorene substrate for CO oxidation at low temperature.
coredata.dc:title: CO oxidation on atomic nickel/phosphorene nanosheet: An efficient single-atom catalyst
